verse_commentaries.commentary: Triple imperative opening creates remarkable escalating urgency: שִׁמְעָה, הַקְשִׁיבָה, הַאֲזִינָה. The phrase 'צֶדֶק' as direct object of 'hear' is striking - the psalmist asks God to 'hear justice' not just 'hear my cry.' Final phrase 'בְּלֹא שִׂפְתֵי מִרְמָה' (without lips of deceit) establishes moral credibility through negation.

lexical_insights.notes: Unusual construction - 'hear justice' rather than 'hear my prayer for justice'
Negative protestatio - establishing prayer's integrity through what it lacks
First person possessive - appears twice in v.1 creating frame

figurative_analysis: Lips personified as potential deceivers
Prayer metaphorically treated as having moral quality (guileless)
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Opening forensic vocabulary establishes legal framework thesis identifies. The triple imperative urgency sets tone for entire plea.

verse_commentaries.commentary: Shift from petition to confident assertion: 'my vindication WILL come from You' (imperfect יֵצֵא suggests certainty). God's eyes as arbiter introduced - key to vision motif culminating in v.15. The phrase 'תֶּחֱזֶינָה מֵישָׁרִים' is poetically dense - 'behold what is upright/straight.'

lexical_insights.notes: Legal verdict imagery - judgment 'going forth' from divine presence
Divine eyes as moral observers - introduces seeing/vision theme
Plural form unusual - 'straight things' or 'upright matters'

figurative_analysis: Judgment personified as entity that 'goes forth'
Eyes as agents of moral discernment
Face as judicial seat from which verdict emerges
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Establishes God's eyes as judge - sets up contrast with predatory enemy eyes (v.11) and culminating vision of God's face (v.15). Seeing motif emerges early.
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: mil-lfā-ney-**KHĀ** mish-pā-**TIY** yē-**TSĒ'** ʿēy-**NEY**-khā te-ḥe-**ZEY**-nāh mēy-shā-**RIY**-m

verse_commentaries.commentary: Remarkable cluster of three testing verbs in perfect tense: בָּחַנְתָּ (probed), פָּקַדְתָּ (visited), צְרַפְתַּנִי (refined). The night visitation suggests temple incubation practice. Triple negation (בַל three times) asserts God found no fault. Final phrase about mouth not transgressing creates body-part continuity with v.1-2.

lexical_insights.notes: Divine testing of heart - first of three examination verbs
Night visitation - possible temple incubation context
Metallurgical metaphor - refining/testing by fire
First of triple בַל negations - emphatic assertion of innocence
Puzzle: does זַמֹּתִי mean 'I planned/purposed' or 'my wickedness'?

figurative_analysis: Refining fire metaphor for divine testing
Night visitation as divine investigative action
Heart as object of divine scrutiny
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Night visitation and awakening frame (vv.3,15) may indicate temple incubation ritual context thesis suggests. Testing verbs establish righteousness credentials for forensic appeal.

verse_commentaries.commentary: Notoriously difficult syntax. The phrase 'לִפְעֻלּוֹת אָדָם בִּדְבַר שְׂפָתֶיךָ' is grammatically perplexing. Does psalmist claim to have avoided or observed 'paths of the violent' (אׇרְחוֹת פָּרִיץ)? The shift to first person verb שָׁמַרְתִּי breaks from previous passive stance.

lexical_insights.notes: Unclear syntactic relationship - 'as for deeds of man' or 'from deeds of man'?
Divine speech as ethical guide - 'by the word of your lips'
Key ambiguity: avoided or kept? Context determines meaning
Can mean 'keep/observe' OR 'guard against/avoid' - lexical ambiguity

figurative_analysis: Paths as metaphor for moral conduct
Divine lips as source of ethical guidance
פָּרִיץ (violent/ruthless one) as archetypal wicked
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: If verse asserts avoidance of violent paths, supports innocence protestation. But syntactic ambiguity undermines interpretive confidence. Divine word (שפתיך) as ethical standard relevant to forensic context.

verse_commentaries.commentary: Shift to body-in-motion imagery: feet and steps held firm in God's paths. The verb תָּמֹךְ (hold fast) is active - psalmist claims agency in maintaining course. Perfect parallelism: steps held → feet not slipped. Triple בַל negation continues from v.3.

lexical_insights.notes: Infinitive absolute? Or perfect? 'Hold fast my steps in your tracks'
Wheel-tracks/ruts - not just paths but established grooves
Third בַל negation - feet absolutely have not slipped

figurative_analysis: Paths/tracks as metaphor for divine guidance
Slipping feet as moral failure
Wheel-ruts (מַעְגְּלוֹת) suggesting well-worn, established way
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Completes innocence protestation (vv.3-5). Feet/steps imagery anticipates spatial encirclement by enemies (v.11). Body part motif continues (heart, mouth, lips, eyes, steps, feet).

verse_commentaries.commentary: Pivot point: shifts from past testing (vv.3-5) to present petition. Direct address אֵל (God) - more intimate than יְהֹוָה. Confident assertion 'כִּי־תַעֲנֵנִי' (for You will answer me) interrupts imperative sequence. Triple imperative pattern resumes but more intimate.

lexical_insights.notes: Perfect tense - 'I HAVE called You' (completed action) yet petition continues
Remarkable confidence - 'because/for You WILL answer me' as factual assertion
Physical gesture - 'incline Your ear toward me' suggests proximity

figurative_analysis: Ear as organ requiring physical inclination - God must bend down
Speech/hearing reciprocity - psalmist's words require divine ear
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Transition from innocence protestation to active petition. Establishes confidence formula that runs through rest of psalm. Hearing motif from v.1 returns with added intimacy.

verse_commentaries.commentary: Call for God to 'display/make wonderful' (הַפְלֵה) His covenant loyalty. Introduces military imagery: right hand as weapon of salvation. First mention of 'enemies' using participial form - those who rise up/oppose. חֹסִים (those taking refuge) identifies righteous as asylum-seekers.

lexical_insights.notes: Hiphil imperative of פלא - 'make wondrous/extraordinary your faithful-loves'
Participial phrase - 'savior of refuge-takers' as divine epithet
Hitpolel participle - 'from those rising up against' (reflexive/intensive)
Right hand as instrument of divine power - military metaphor

figurative_analysis: Right hand as weapon/tool of salvation
Refuge-taking as spatial metaphor for trust
Rising up as hostile military posture
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Introduces enemy threat that dominates vv.8-14. Right hand imagery returns in v.13. Refuge/protection language sets up wing-shadow metaphor in v.8. Military salvation theme begins.
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: haf-**LĒH** ḥa-sā-dhey-**KHĀ** mō-**SHI**-yaʿ ḥō-**SIY**-m mim-mith-qō-mə-**MIY**-m biy-miy-**NE**-khā

verse_commentaries.commentary: Two of the most striking protective metaphors in Psalms: 'apple of eye' (אִישׁוֹן בַּת־עָיִן) and 'shadow of wings' (צֵל כְּנָפֶיךָ). The pupil metaphor emphasizes psalmist's preciousness and vulnerability. Wing-shadow evokes both maternal bird and temple cherubim imagery simultaneously.

lexical_insights.notes: Literally 'like pupil, daughter of eye' - double construct intensifying preciousness
Wing-shadow - cherubim throne imagery OR bird protection metaphor
Hiphil - causative 'cause me to be hidden' - active divine concealment

figurative_analysis: Pupil/daughter-of-eye as most precious, vulnerable, protected part
Wings as protective canopy - avian or cherubic
Shadow as refuge space - negative space becomes positive sanctuary
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Wing-shadow likely temple cherubim (see thesis discussion of ark imagery). Sets up contrast between divine protective gaze (v.8) and predatory enemy gaze (v.11). Intimacy of metaphors balances forensic distance of earlier verses.
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: shom-rē-**NIY** kə-'iy-**SHŌN** bath-**ʿĀ**-yin bə-**TSĒL** kə-nā-**FEY**-khā tas-tiy-**RĒ**-niy

verse_commentaries.commentary: Shift to enemy description. Triple identification: רְשָׁעִים (wicked), אֹיְבַי (my enemies), בְּנֶפֶשׁ (in life/soul - intensifier). Verb יַקִּיפוּ (encircle) introduces spatial siege language that dominates vv.9-11. The ז֣וּ before שַׁדּ֑וּנִי is grammatically odd.

lexical_insights.notes: זוּ is puzzle - demonstrative pronoun 'this'? Or זה (which)? Syntax unclear
Literally 'my enemies in/with soul' - mortal/deadly enemies
Surround/encircle - begins spatial entrapment theme

figurative_analysis: Encirclement as military siege metaphor
בְּנֶפֶשׁ (in/with soul) intensifies to mortal threat
Face-to-face confrontation implied by מִפְּנֵי
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Begins enemy characterization section (vv.9-12). Encirclement language creates spatial urgency requiring divine intervention (v.13). Contrasts with protective enclosure of wing-shadow (v.8).
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: mip-**NĒY** rə-shā-ʿiy-**M** **ZŪ** sha-**DŪ**-niy 'ō-yə-**VAY** bə-**NE**-fesh yaq-**QIY**-fū ʿā-**LĀY**

verse_commentaries.commentary: Body part focus intensifies: חֶלְבָּמוֹ (their fat) and פִּימוֹ (their mouth). The phrase 'חֶלְבָּמוֹ סָּגְרוּ' is puzzling - 'their fat they have closed'? Idiom for callousness/insensitivity? Mouths speaking בְגֵאוּת (in/with pride/arrogance).

lexical_insights.notes: PUZZLE: 'their fat they closed' - idiom? Emendation to 'their heart'?
Mouth speaks arrogance - note singular פִּי with plural subject

figurative_analysis: Fat as symbol of insensitivity or prosperity?
Closed as metaphor for hardness/imperviousness
Mouth as instrument of arrogance
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Body part characterization of enemies parallels psalmist's body parts (lips, mouth, heart, feet). Creates moral contrast through somatic imagery. Arrogance theme anticipates lion's predatory confidence (v.12).

verse_commentaries.commentary: Spatial language intensifies: אַשֻּׁרֵינוּ עַתָּה - 'our steps, now' creates immediacy. Verb סְבָבוּנוּ (they surround us) echoes יַקִּיפוּ from v.9. Enemy eyes introduced - predatory gaze set against divine gaze (v.2) and desired beatific vision (v.15). Phrase לִנְטוֹת בָּאָרֶץ (to stretch out on earth) suggests lion crouching.

lexical_insights.notes: Our steps - plural shifts from 'my' (earlier) to 'our' (corporate?)
They set their eyes - predatory focus/intent gaze
To stretch out/incline in earth - crouching position? Taking possession?

figurative_analysis: Eyes as predatory hunting tools - tracking prey
Surrounding/hemming as military or hunting strategy
Stretching on earth as beast preparing to pounce
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Creates vision theology triangle: God's righteous eyes (v.2) vs enemy predatory eyes (v.11) vs psalmist's desired vision of God's face (v.15). Spatial entrapment reaches peak before call for divine intervention.
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: 'ash-shu-rēy-**NŪ** ʿa-**TĀH** sə-vā-**VŪ**-nū ʿēy-nēy-**HEM** yā-**SHIY**-thū lin-**TŌTH** bā-**'Ā**-rets

verse_commentaries.commentary: Climactic animal simile: enemy as lion. Shift from plural enemies to singular הוּ (he/it) - archetypal evil. Two leonine images: אַרְיֵה (lion) eager to tear, כְּפִיר (young lion/maned lion) crouching in hiding. Hunting vocabulary: יִכְסוֹף (eager/long for), לִטְרֹף (to tear prey), יֹשֵׁב בְּמִסְתָּרִים (sitting in ambush).

lexical_insights.notes: 'His likeness is like a lion' - doubled comparison creates intensity
Literally 'longs/yearns to tear' - combines desire + violence
Young/strong lion sitting (participle) in hiding places - ambush posture

figurative_analysis: Lion as apex predator - ultimate threat
Ambush/hiding as stealth hunting strategy
Tearing as violent consumption
Longing/eagerness anthropomorphizes beast - makes it more menacing
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Climax of enemy characterization. Lion metaphor common in laments (Ps 7:2, 10:9, 22:13, 57:4). Sets up military language of divine counter-attack (v.13). Predatory eagerness contrasts with psalmist's eager desire for God's face (v.15).
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: dim-yō-**NŌ** kə-'ar-**YĒH** yikh-**SŌF** lit-**RŌF** wə-khikh-**FIY**-r yō-**SHĒV** bə-mis-tā-**RIY**-m

verse_commentaries.commentary: Four rapid-fire imperatives mobilizing God: קוּמָה (arise), קַדְּמָה (confront), הַכְרִיעֵהוּ (bring down), פַּלְּטָה (deliver). Military confrontation imagery: God with sword (חַרְבֶּךָ) confronting enemy face-to-face (פָנָיו). Note shift back to singular enemy matching lion metaphor.

lexical_insights.notes: 'Arise...confront his face' - military readiness + face-to-face encounter
Hiphil - 'cause to bow down/bring low/prostrate' - military defeat
Deliver my soul from wicked - is חַרְבֶּךָ sword of God or sword of wicked?

figurative_analysis: Arising as military mobilization
Confronting face = direct combat engagement
Sword as divine weapon of judgment
Bowing down as defeat/submission
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Divine counter-attack answers spatial entrapment (vv.9-11). Right hand from v.7 returns implied. Sword imagery unique to this petition section. Confrontation language inverts enemy's predatory confrontation.
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: qū-**MĀH** yə-hō-**WĀH** qad-**MĀH** fā-nāy-**W** hakh-riy-**ʿĒ**-hū pal-**LTĀH** naf-**SHIY** mē-rā-**SHĀʿ** ḥar-**BE**-khā

verse_commentaries.commentary: EXTREMELY difficult verse. Multiple interpretive cruxes: Who are 'treasured ones'? Is their belly-filling positive (provision) or negative (materialism)? What is חֶלֶד - fleeting/world/life? Verse may contrast wicked prosperity (חֵלֶק בַּחַיִּים - portion in life) with righteous hope (v.15), but syntax resists clarity.

lexical_insights.notes: PUZZLE: 'from men of חֶלֶד, their portion in life' - is חֶלֶד temporal (fleeting) or spatial (world)?
Your treasure/hidden things fill their belly - positive or negative? Whose belly?
'Satisfied sons' - generations prospering, but is this wicked or righteous?
'Leave their excess to their children' - intergenerational wealth transfer

figurative_analysis: Belly as receptacle of satisfaction/prosperity
Portion/inheritance language throughout
Treasure/hidden things as divine or earthly goods?
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Critical for thesis contrast with v.15. If v.14 describes wicked prosperity (most likely), then חֶלְקָם בַּחַיִּים (portion in life) opposes psalmist's portion = beholding God (v.15). Satisfaction (יִשְׂבְּעוּ) language sets up psalmist's satisfaction (אֶשְׂבְּעָה) with divine vision.
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: mim-thiy-m-yā-dhə-**KHĀ**  yə-hō-**WĀH** **MIM**-thiy-m mē-**ḤE**-ledh ḥel-**QĀM** **BA**-ḥay-yiy-m ū-**TSƏ**-fū-nə-khā tə-mal-**LĒ'** vit-**NĀM** yis-**BʿŪ** vā-**NIY**-m wə-hin-**NIY**-ḥū yith-**RĀM** lə-ʿō-lə-lēy-**HEM**

verse_commentaries.commentary: Theological crescendo. Sharp contrast particle אֲנִי (I/as for me) opposes v.14. Three key phrases: בְּצֶדֶק (in righteousness), אֶחֱזֶה פָנֶיךָ (behold Your face), בְּהָקִיץ (when awaking). Final word תְּמוּנָתֶךָ (Your form/image) echoes Num 12:8 (Moses seeing God's תְּמוּנָה). Satisfaction vocabulary (אֶשְׂבְּעָה) directly opposes v.14 (יִשְׂבְּעוּ).

lexical_insights.notes: Core claim: 'I in righteousness will behold Your face' - temple theophany language
Inclusio with v.1 צֶדֶק - righteousness frames entire psalm
Behold divine face - dangerous privilege (cf. Ex 33:20), temple entrance right
When awaking - morning? resurrection? spiritual awakening? temple incubation?
Be satisfied with Your form/likeness - echoes Gen 1:26 image language, Num 12:8 Moses vision

figurative_analysis: Face as divine presence requiring access
Awakening as transition state - spatial or temporal or spiritual
Form/image as visible manifestation of invisible God
Satisfaction as ultimate human fulfillment
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: CLIMAX of entire psalm. Resolves forensic appeal, enemy threat, protective petition into mystical theological vision. Radically redefines prosperity: not belly-filling (v.14) but face-beholding. Awakening may indicate temple incubation ritual framing whole psalm (night visitation v.3 → morning awakening v.15). תְּמוּנָה connects to Moses's unique privilege (Num 12:8), suggesting psalmist claims comparable intimacy.

thematic_threads: Righteousness inclusio: צֶדֶק (v.1) and בְּצֶדֶק (v.15) frame entire psalm with moral concern
Body part somatic theology: lips, mouth, heart, ear, eyes, hand, feet, steps create embodied prayer throughout
Vision/seeing motif progression: God's eyes behold uprightness (v.2) → guard as pupil of eye (v.8) → enemy eyes track (v.11) → I behold Your face (v.15)
Triple negation pattern using בַל: vv.3,5 - rhetorical excess asserting absolute innocence
Night-awakening frame: night visitation (v.3) and awakening (v.15) may indicate temple incubation ritual
Satisfaction contrast climax: wicked/their sons satisfied with earthly portion (v.14) vs psalmist satisfied with divine vision (v.15)
Spatial language: encirclement by enemies (vv.9-11) requiring divine intervention and protective enclosure (wing shadow v.8)
Shift from plural enemies to singular archetypal lion (v.12) intensifies threat before divine response
interesting_questions: What is the precise meaning and function of the puzzling phrase 'חֶלְבָּמוֹ סָּגְרוּ' (their fat they closed, v.10) - is this idiomatic for hardheartedness, or should it be emended to 'their heart'?

How does the 'awakening' (בְּהָקִיץ) in v.15 relate to the night visitation (פָּקַדְתָּ לַּיְלָה) in v.3 - does this frame indicate actual temple incubation ritual where suppliants slept in sanctuary?
Why does the psalmist claim to 'behold God's face' (אֶחֱזֶה פָנֶיךָ) in v.15 given the theological danger and prohibition of seeing God's face in Exodus 33:20?
What is the syntactic and theological function of the notoriously difficult verse 14 - does it describe wicked prosperity (setting up v.15 contrast) or petition for righteous provision?
How does תְּמוּנָה (form/image) in v.15 relate to Moses's unique privilege of seeing God's תְּמוּנָה (Num 12:8) and the image of God (צֶלֶם) in Genesis 1:26?
Why does the text shift between singular and plural enemy references, particularly the move to singular 'lion' in v.12 after plural 'they' in vv.9-11?
What is the meaning of the rare/puzzling word זוּ in v.9 ('רְשָׁעִים זוּ שַׁדּוּנִי') - demonstrative, relative, or textual corruption?
How does the phrase 'בְּצֵל כְּנָפֶיךָ' (shadow of Your wings, v.8) function - as maternal bird imagery, temple cherubim metaphor, or deliberate dual valence?
What does חֶלֶד mean in v.14 ('מֵחֶלֶד') - 'fleeting' (temporal), 'world' (spatial), or something else? How does this affect the wicked vs. righteous contrast?
Why does the psalmist use such extraordinarily strong righteousness claims (vv.3-5) - is this hyperbole, ritual language for temple entrance, or sincere moral confidence?
How does Psalm 17 relate intertextually to Psalms 16 and 73, which also contrast earthly prosperity with divine presence as ultimate good?
What is the significance of the triple imperative opening (שִׁמְעָה, הַקְשִׁיבָה, הַאֲזִינָה in v.1) and the quadruple imperative in v.13 (קוּמָה, קַדְּמָה, הַכְרִיעֵהוּ, פַּלְּטָה)?
synthesis_notes:
LEXICON: Focus on חֶלֶד (v.14), זוּ (v.9), חֶלְבָּמוֹ סָּגְרוּ (v.10), תְּמוּנָה (v.15), בְּהָקִיץ (v.15)
CONCORDANCE: Track 'behold face of God' phrases, בְּצֵל כְּנָפֶיךָ formula across Psalms, temple entrance righteousness claims (Pss 15, 24), satisfaction (שבע) with God vs material goods
FIGURATIVE: All verses with body part imagery (vv.1-3,8,10-11,15), protective metaphors (v.8), predator imagery (v.12)
COMMENTARY: Especially vv.4,10,14 (syntactic puzzles), v.15 (seeing God's face/form), v.3 and v.15 (night/awakening frame)
THEOLOGICAL: Temple incubation practices, theodicy and competing satisfactions (v.14-15), righteousness protestation genre and ANE legal background
